text:

text:

text: After several Steven Segal films in a row, you'd think bad guys would know to avoid rooms that contain both him & a PoolTable

text: Odd that politicians who change their mind are often criticized by those who don’t, as though ossified thoughts were a virtue

text: Not all rectangles are squares, but all squares are rectangles. Same for Dinosaurs. So NBA’s Toronto Raptors are not Birds.

text: I'm thinking somebody should invent black bleach, which would get white stains out of black garments.

text: When a Doctor’s prognosis is bad, we want to seek a second opinion. But when a prognosis is good we’re somehow okay with it.

text: I fear a future in which Autocorrect achieves consciousness, becomes our texting overlord, and destabilizes civilization.

text: Just up the force until the immovable object is obliterated, after which it's irrelevant that your object was immovable.

text: #WhenIWasYourAge it was people who were smart, and phones that were dumb.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge James Bond was probably infected with multiple STDs.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenMyParentsWereYourAge “In God We Trust" was neither on our money, the Pledge of Allegiance, or the front wall of Congress
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge The weather started feeling cold in September.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge You could kiss your loved-one goodbye at the airport gate. And return home.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge America launched its own Astronauts into space — with its own Spaceships.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge We cured diseases and went to the Moon, benchmarking our usage of the word “Awesome."
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge Second-hand smoke was when somebody offered you a toke on whatever they were puffing.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge Extracting ketchup from its narrow-necked glass bottle occasionally made you question the laws of gravity.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge We consumed Twinkles, Cool Whip, and Yoo-hoo, without questioning their chemical composition.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge A photograph lived inside your camera, cloaked in mystery for weeks, until you took exactly 35 more photos.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge Photographs were records of your life experience, and not the life experience itself.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge Pluto was a planet. T-Rex dragged his tail. And the Brontosaurus was always chewing vegetation.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: October — a popular month in which to be born, corresponding with conception on New Year’s day of the Gregorian Calendar.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Thanks to all Birthday well-wishers in the Twitterverse.  Born in 1958, yet I don’t feel a day over 57.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The @MartianMovie — where you learn all the ways that being Scientifically Literate can save your life.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Evidence that the @MartianMovie is fantasy: The USA & China cooperate with one another in Space.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Evidence that the @MartianMovie is fantasy: All who make important decisions are scientifically literate.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Guns don’t kill people. Bullets kill people. Fired from guns, brandished by people, who shoot you by accident or on purpose.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Kudos to @NASANewHorizons for taking us from a fuzzy blip to a face-on closeup of Pluto’s Moon Charonpic.twitter.com/NZIebO5XCg

text: SPACE ALIEN: "Why does your UN have a Security Council?” HUMAN: “Our leaders argue there about how & why we kill one another”

text: Imagine a world where Nations find the search for life in the Universe more interesting than the taking of life on Earth.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Ed @Snowden, after discussing everything from Chemistry to the Constitution on #StarTalk, you're a patriot to me. Stay safe.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Ed @Snowden, many call you Hero, others Traitor. Whatever else you are, you’re a Geek to me. What do you say to those labels?
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Ed @Snowden, If you visit Mars, I'd bet any life forms there will greet you with a sip of that water -- and a tourist visa.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Feeling a Geek vibe. Edward @Snowden, the man behind the global mass surveillance revelations. Welcome to @twitter.

text: Congratulations to @TrevorNoah tonight. @TheDailyShow's new opening credits now show Earth rotating in the correct direction.

text: Oops. Left out an important one:  Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.

text: Proper uses of the word Super:  Superman, Supernova, Super Duper, Super Bowl, Supercharged, Superconductivity, Super Mario.

text: Resist the Hype: The size of today’s “Super” moon is to next month’s full moon as a 16.07 inch pizza is to a 16.00 inch pizza
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Attend culinary school. Prepare a delicious dish. People ask what's your secret? The answer is: you attended culinary school.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Sept 23: Happy Equinox to all Earthlings. One of only two annual days when the Sun everywhere rises due East & sets due West.

text: If your Personal Beliefs deny what’s objectively true about the world, then they're more accurately called Personal Delusions
author: deGrasseTyson

text: There's no greater incentive to lie than the threat of punishment for telling the truth.

text: If your body were bolted to the ground when Earth stopped rotating, then your head would snap off, and it would roll due east
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I’m just sayin'
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If Earth stopped rotating, everyone not bolted to the ground would fall over and roll due east at the speed of a jet plane.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: 2015 has the earliest possible MemorialDay & the latest possible LaborDay, granting the longest possible “unofficial" summer.

text: An informed opinion is never based on somebody else’s opinion, lest you empower others to do your thinking for you.

text: Jupiter is 11x wider than Earth. But Earth is only 5x wider than Pluto.  So Jovians surely demoted us to DwarfPlanet long ago
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Any time we're impressed by what a non-human animal does, it's simply because we previously underestimated its intelligence.

text: Roses are Red, Violets are, I suppose, Violet.

text: Odd that we select the heads of agencies by who is most qualified. But we select Presidents by whose personality we like best

text: Summer Thought: If you convert a bug zapper to a human zapper, scaling by body mass, you’d receive a jolt of 50 billion volts

text: Odd. Those who feel superior are often compelled to tell others, presumably because it’s not otherwise obvious to anyone.

text: Dear Twittererse: I am a servant of your curiosity. And it’s a privilege to share with you my cosmic musings in this medium.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Passed 4-million Twitter followers over the weekend. A milestone only because we count in base 10.  In base 16 it’s 3D0900.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I’ll take the Heebies, not the Jeebies. The Flim, not the Flam. And I’ll always take the Proof, with or without the Pudding
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I further like the Hocus, but not the Pocus. The Hodge, but not the Podge. And definitely the Boogie without the Oogie.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I’m a fan of Nooks, but not Crannies. The Kit, but not the Caboodle. And the Hanky, but not the Panky.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: And yes, over the years, my relationship with Pluto has been strictly Plutonic.

RIP ELDoctorow (1931-2015)

text: The next time anybody asks me about my religion, I think I’ll reply “Geek Orthodox”
author: deGrasseTyson

text:
Dear Pluto,
Lookin’ good. But you’re still a Dwarf Planet — get over it.
Love, Neil deGrasse Tysonpic.twitter.com/qBBD9feG6e
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Were it not for @NASA & kindred programs of discovery, I wonder what hope would remain for our species to rise above itself.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #PlutoFacts: @NewHorizons2015 went 4-billion miles to buzzcut Pluto by 120,000 miles. A hole-in-one on a 2-mile golf shot.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #PlutoFacts: Pluto would fit comfortably between New York & Dallas. Between Rome & Moscow.  Between Perth & Melbourne.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #PlutoFacts: In 1979, Pluto crossed Neptune’s orbit, and for 20 years was the eighth “planet” in the solar system.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #PlutoFacts Pluto’s primary moon Charon is so large that their mutual center-of-mass lies not within Pluto but in empty space
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #PlutoFacts: Ever since Pluto was discovered in 1930, it has completed barely 1/3 of its own 248 year orbit around the Sun.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #PlutoFacts:  Earth’s Moon is five times more massive than Pluto.  Get over it.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: What the Twitterverse needs right now is even more Pluto. Give me some space...
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Evidence for global warming comes in many forms.pic.twitter.com/zN3U83ETZH

text: As always, I celebrate my leap seconds with very tiny bottles of champagne.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Since 1972, after we discovered we keep better time than Earth does, we’ve added 25 leap secs. Done only on June 30 & Dec 31.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: June 30th's leap second will manifest as an extra second in the last minute of the day, Greenwich time. ( 7h 59m 60s  PM  ET)
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The Moon continually tugs on Earth’s rotation, slowing us down bit by bit. To compensate, Tuesday, June 30 gets a leap second
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Name-calling is what happens when you desperately want to argue, but you are in fact inarticulate.

text: Curious fact that those who never fail are also those who never truly succeed.

text: For Algebra Geeks: If the thickness of a pizza is A, and its radius is Z, and pi is just PI, then its volume is V = PIZZA.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If the cheese on a 14-inch pizza falls just 1-inch shy of the crust, the pie is missing 30% of the cheese that could be there
author: deGrasseTyson

text: A 14-inch pizza is 154 square inches of food.  Nearly twice as large as the 78 square inches of a 10-inch pie.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Odd that pizza is sold by the inch, but consumed by the square-inch. This fact confuses assessment of pricing and toppings.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Last one: The Latinized name for Earth is Terra. If you are human "of the Earth" you are Terrable. (Just kidding, Earthlings)
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Want More? The Moon's Latinized name is Luna.  If you are "of the Moon” youre simply “Lunar”.  Lunatics are something else..
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Not that anybody asked, but the Sun's Latinized name is Sol.  If you are "of the Sun" you are simply “Solar”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Venus is the Roman goddess of love & sexuality. And so medical doctors assigned Venereal - “of Venus” to all related diseases
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Ceres is the Roman goddess of agriculture and grain crops, which indeed gives us our breakfast word Cereal --  "of Ceres".
author: deGrasseTyson

text: From Venus? Then you’re Venusian. But the proper term is Venereal. Unfortunately Doctors nabbed it before Astrophysicists did
author: deGrasseTyson

text: And it seems to me that any life forms we discover within Jupiter’s icy moon Europa would rightly be called Europeans.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Seems to me, if we discover any life forms from the Vega star system (constellation Lyrae) they'd rightly be called Vegans.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: At The Who concert listening to 71yr old R. Daltrey & 70 yr old P. Townsend sing their lyric "I hope I die before I get old."
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Thinking the World today is particularly violent? During World War II, an average of 1,000 people were killed per hour

text: Just an FYI: Well-funded Political Action Committees are not buying your vote, they're buying media influence over your vote.

text: When flight attendants say "Cabin is pressurized for your comfort” they mean "so you don't suffocate from oxygen deprivation"

text: Okay to encourage others to pull themselves up by their bootstraps. But if you do, just remember, some people have no boots.

text: If you removed all the arteries, veins, & capillaries from a person's body, and tied them end-to-end, the person will die.

text: Our “Common Sense" is not derived from what is true in Nature but from the limits on how our senses interact with Nature.

text: Try as I might, I cannot resist this geek-laden, lisp-inducing, annual utterance: "May the fourth be with you."

text: The less evidence we have for what we believe is certain, the more violently we defend beliefs against those who don't agree.

text: The total number "What-are-the-odds?" moments that can happen is so large, we should instead think of rare events as common.

text: Okay to not know. But when you don't know, yet think you know, and wield power in that ignorance, it's a recipe for disaster.

text: Now that Cars no longer use Hubcaps, and are no longer available to fling, I’ve seen many fewer fuzzy fotos of flying saucers
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If we were honest about shortcomings of human physiology then "optical illusions” would instead be labeled “brain failures”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Untruth in Advertising: “Mega" is the metric prefix for million, so the Mega-millions Lottery should pay trillions of dollars
author: deGrasseTyson

text: My favorite cold temperature is forty below zero - where Celsius equals Fahrenheit. No need to specify the scale you’re using
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The ten coldest temperatures ever recorded in NYC: 252 252 252 252 252 251 251 251 248 & 247 kelvins. All before 1944.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder if Accountants feel the urge to represent negative Temperatures in parenthesis.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Two years ago today, Feb 15, 2013, Earth got slammed by a 12,000 ton asteroid traveling 40,000 mph: http://bit.ly/1AbTesS
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happened in 2006. Time to "Get over it!” Yeah, I said it. Now it’s on a T-shirt http://bit.ly/1zSYeDQ pic.twitter.com/egp13sf2oF
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Would be cool if space aliens landed on Earth and instead asked, “Take me to your common people!"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Good education is not what fills your head with facts but what stimulates curiosity. You then learn for the rest of your life
author: deGrasseTyson

text: You should all know by now that if you accuse me of being a Nerd or a Geek, I’ll simply take it as a compliment and move on.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Had to wait in line to renew a Passport allowing me to visit members of my own species across artificially conceived borders.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: NBC camera showed Orion rising over Arizona. Announcer Al Michaels uttered the world “Astrophysics”.  All is well.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: A 50-yd field goal, in the University of Phoenix Stadium, deflects about one-third inch to the right due to Earth's rotation
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Momentum & Energy transfer. Elastic & Inelastic collisions. Spin-stabilized Prolate Spheroids. American Football is Physics.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just an FYI:  A 250 lb football player, running 15 mph, has more kinetic energy than a bullet fired from an AK-47 rifle.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Occasionally I wonder what a football game would be like if played by Zombies. Would be slower, but oh so much more violent.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Odd: Sporty cars in TV ads are always driven sideways. Wheel inventors Trog & Lodyte might wonder if we grasped the principle
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Enjoying colorful fireworks in Arizona? Thank Aluminum Barium Calcium Chlorine Copper Iron Nitrogen Oxygen Sodium & Strontium
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder is Sharks feel sorry for humans because we get only two sets of teeth, rather than unlimited.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Slightly underinflated balls are easier to grab & catch, but their aerodynamics are no different from properly inflated balls
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If Gridirons were timelines, w/ BigBang at one goal, then Cavemen to now spans thickness of single turf-blade at other goal.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Odd: “Patriots" derives from the American Revolutionary war against enemy England. Yet they proudly hail from “New” England.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Not that anybody asked, but the International Space Station travels four miles in 4/5 of a second.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: At top speeds of more than Mach 2, an Air Force F16 Jet can be up to four miles away, yet reach the Stadium within 10 seconds
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The @SuperBowl, seen through the lens of an astrophysicist.  Starting now.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: As does any month that begins on a Sunday, February this year has a "Friday the 13th”. Which means March has one too.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I love the smell of the Universe — in the evening.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: You can neither cajole nor charm the laws of physics into agreeing with you if your ideas aren't based in objective realities
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Not enough of us reflect on how modern civilization pivots on the discoveries of just a few intellectually restless people.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: For the Patriots to blame a change in temperature for 15% lower-pressures, requires balls to be inflated with 125-degree air.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Chill. Earth is 17 trillion times the mass of Monday’s Asteroid. Same as the Space Shuttle’s launch mass to an eyebrow hair.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I dream of a world where the truth is what shapes people's politics, rather than politics shaping what people think is true.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Jan 21, 2015: The 1989 film “Back to the Future II” showed life on Oct 21, 2015. So we’ve got 9 Months to invent Hoverboards.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: You never see US Citizens that hate to pay Taxes, long to live in places with lower rates, like HongKong, Pakistan, or Russia
author: deGrasseTyson

text: if I am ever abducted by aliens, I just may be compelled to ask, “Do you have Hoverboards on your home planet?"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: And you thought 2015 was uninteresting: @JohnAllenPaulos reminds me that in binary, the year is Palindromic: 11111011111
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Yup, A StarTalk storefront just opened. It’s authorized & I’m told it's Badass. http://bit.ly/1y4LDwA pic.twitter.com/QGyTS9xiKm
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Students who earn straight "A"s in school do so not because of good Teachers but in spite of bad Teachers.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Wouldn't it be cool if Zombies & Vampires became human if we bit them first? Somebody needs to test that hypothesis.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Obama authorized North Korea sanctions over cyber hacking.  Solution there, it seems to me, is to create unhackable systems.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happy Hew Year to all on the Gregorian calendar. Today, Earth completes yet another 939,950,000 km journey around the Sun.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: By 2015, Apollo 11 will be as long ago as 1923 was to the Moon landing itself. And I don’t know what we have to show for it.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: This hour, Happy New Year to the fishes who live in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean & to parts of Brazil sharing their time.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If interested, my four fave Twilight Zone Episodes: “The Invaders” “To Serve Man” “Monsters on Maple Street” & “The Shelter”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Clocks on the Prime Meridian track GMT - Greenwich Mean Time. As kid, I always wanted there to be GHT - Greenwich Happy Time.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Although clocks on the Prime Meridian keep "Universal Time", I’m quite sure Aliens across the actual universe don’t care.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happy NewYear to Greenwich, England & Ouagadougou, BurkinaFaso & everybody else in the zeroth time zone of the Prime Meridian
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Hold all calls. Emails will have to wait. Once again, I am lost within the @SyFy channel's Twilight Zone New Years  Marathon.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happy New Year to Japan, Korea, and others in your time zone, 14 hours ahead of us on the East Coast of the United States.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Reflections on what became my most retweeted tweet:  https://www.facebook.com/notes/neil-degrasse-tyson/my-most-retweeted-tweet/10152533257800869 …
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Imagine a world in which we are all enlightened by objective truths rather than offended by them.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Santa knows Physics: Of all colors, Red Light penetrates fog best. That's why Benny the Blue-nosed reindeer never got the gig
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Merry Christmas to all. A Pagan holiday (BC) becomes a Religious holiday (AD). Which then becomes a Shopping holiday (USA).
author: deGrasseTyson

text: On this day long ago, a child was born who, by age 30, would transform the world. Happy Birthday Isaac Newton b. Dec 25, 1642
author: deGrasseTyson

text: QUESTION: ThIs year, what do all the world's Muslims and Jews call December 25th? ANSWER: Thursday
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If we had twelve fingers, there’d be no middle finger to flip at people with whom you’ve run out of words to communicate.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If we had 12 fingers, I wonder whether the  Bill of Rights to the American Consitiution would have been 12 amendments long.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If we all had twelve fingers, I wonder whether Moses would have delivered twelve commandments from God, instead of ten.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: December 20, 1975: 17 years old, I visited Carl Sagan at Cornell University. His Appt. Book that day.pic.twitter.com/tlWgQwsrqO
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Always liked Dawn as a name, evoking the start of Day. But we’re overdue for people to be named Dusk, the start of Night.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Why Stephen Hawking is badass:http://youtu.be/gek-cUzfpyU
author: deGrasseTyson

text: On some issues, I’m a staunch Conservative — like curtailing greenhouse gas emissions so that we can Conserve the environment
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Sad over today’s state of the world? During the six years of World War II, an average of 1,000 people were killed — per hour.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Aliens, seeing Humans kill over land, politics, religion, & skin color, would surely ask, “What the f*%k is wrong with you?"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just because you can't figure out how ancient civilizations built stuff, doesn't mean they got help from Aliens.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Of talent, some might say you’ve “Got it down to a science”. But only when it’s also beautiful have you “Raised to an Art”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Religion was taught in Sunday School, not in your Science Classroom.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: The Soviet KGB would’ve killed for the surveillance & checkpoint measures that are common in the USA today
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: There were ten known asteroids with orbits crossing Earth's. Now, we know more than ten-thousand.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We actually used a sheet of paper laced with carbon to make a carbon copy — “the cc:" -- of a Letter.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: People were never "living with their disease". We cured them. Or they died from it.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Your home telephone could drop to the floor thousands of times and never break.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We made phone calls in Phone Booths, which is also where Superman occasionally changed his clothes.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: On average, the Moon was about 1.5 meters closer to Earth than it is today.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Earth's daily rotation was about a half a millisecond faster than today.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Before Xerox copiers, we all got high in elementary school by smelling mimeograph ink.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: When you fell off the monkey-bars in the playground you landed on cement.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We used large Maps made of paper, and none of us could ever re-fold them back the way they came.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: You knew where & when the constellations could be found in the sky by using your “Brain App”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We went to the Moon -- nine times. Today, in low Earth-Orbit, we boldly go where hundreds have gone before.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: People were skinnier.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Being "all thumbs" meant you were clumsy.  Today it means you’re good at texting.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We had to open all doors by ourselves. None of them knew we were coming.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: It took a week to learn whether your photos came out okay.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Pluto was a planet, but those "in the know" all knew its days were numbered.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The greatest examples of human control over Evolution are found in Agriculture and in #TheDogShow.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Thanksgiving in the USA. Of a time when food was scarce. Now abundant, at dinner we over-eat even more than we usually do.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Times Have Changed: Officer kills an unarmed Black man, spawning National protests. When I grew up, this was just local news.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder if Atheists eat at T.G.I. Fridays.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Our image of evil space aliens surely derives from a fear that they will treat us just as we treat one another.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Odd that drivers of fuel efficient cars often get more green-praise than those who chose to live where they can walk to work.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Yup. We’re soft landing on a comet today. Normally my “We” means @NASA. But in this case it’s @ESA, the European Space Agency
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Mysteries of #Interstellar: In this unreal future, they teach unscientific things in science class. Oh, wait. That is real.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Mysteries of #Interstellar: Can’t imagine a future where escaping Earth via wormhole is a better plan than just fixing Earth.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder if Farm Animals think deep thoughts while standing around doing nothing. I also wonder if they wonder the same of us
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: They explore a planet near a Black Hole. Personally, I’d stay as far the hell away from BlackHoles as I can
author: deGrasseTyson

text: REMINDER: Never look to me for opinions on new films. All I do is highlight the science one might or might not find in them.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar, if you didn’t understand the plot, there is no published book to help you.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar, if you didn’t understand the physics, try Kip Thorne’s highly readable Bbook “The Science of Interstellar"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: On another planet, around another star, in another part of the galaxy, two guys get into a fist fight.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: Of the leading characters (all of whom are scientists or engineers) half are women. Just an FYI.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: You observe great Tidal Waves from great Tidal Forces, of magnitude that orbiting a Black Hole might create
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: The producers knew exactly how, why, & when you’d achieve zero-G in space.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Relativity. Gravity. Quantum. Electrodynamics. Evolution. Each of these theories is true, whether or not you believe in them.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: Experience Einstein’s Relativity of Time as no other feature film has shown.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: And in the real universe, strong gravitational fields measurably slow passage of time relative to others.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In #Interstellar: All leading characters, including McConaughey, Hathaway, Chastain, & Caine play a scientist or engineer.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Stay calm. Just because Republicans took control over the Senate, doesn't mean Global Warming is any less true than before.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If voters thought entirely for themselves, then Political Action Committees & attack-ads would have no influence on elections
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Proud to be Homo sapiens. A curious species with DNA compelling us to explore, even if doing so puts your own life at risk.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Pope Francis announced that he now embraces the science of Evolution & the Big Bang. Hmm. I wonder if he just watched Cosmos?
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In the aerospace community, uncrewed Rocket Failures are simply Launches that are rich in learning opportunities.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In Court you can win even if ideas you defend are not true.  But in science, Nature is the ultimate judge, jury & executioner
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder if social media atheists ever use "OMG".  If so, they probably intended to type "OYG".
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I’m quite sure that Frogs were into Hip-Hop long before the music industry was.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder what aliens would think of human biology, upon learning we spend 1/3 of each Earth rotation in a semi-comatose state
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The objective truths of the world are controversial only to people who are both under-informed and who like to argue.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Mere coincidence? After the musical CATS  closed on Broadway in 2000, Cats started showing up all over the internet.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Today’s date is 10 / 10 / 2014.  It’s so rare that it will never happen again.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If Picasso were reincarnated I wonder if he’d return as a flounder, or other fish with both eyes on the same side of its head
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Plants get their energy from the Sun. Herbivores from plants. Carnivores from herbivores. In the end, we're all solar powered
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Thanks for all the Birthday wishes yesterday. It’s been fun these 56 years, swirling around the Sun at 67,000 miles per hour.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder how much talent has evaporated from the world, for lack of ambition to drive it.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If Detroit added a pro-sports team & called it the Bears, the City could boast it was home to the Lions and Tigers and Bears.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just passed my 4000th tweet -- an arbitrary moment enhanced by base-ten. Thanks to all for interest in these mental musings.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: There are surely problems in the universe so advanced that our human brain cannot see them as problems in need of solution.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I think not enough good Hot Chocolate is served in the world. A comfort food without equal.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: After 20 years & 5 championships, Derek Jeter’s last game (ever) in Yankee Stadium tonight. Won with a walk off hit. Farewell
author: deGrasseTyson

text: A news headline you hardly ever see:  "Psychic Wins the Lottery Again"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Apart from common names, stars are generally ID'ed in order of brightness within a constellation, using the Greek alphabet.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just an FYI: Earth’s South Magnetic Pole is actually in the North. That’s why the North tip of a compass needle points there.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: “Arctic" derives from Arktos, the Greek word for Bear. The Arctic's got em. (For now.) The Ant-Arctic doesn't.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In the North, the shadow of a sundial’s gnomon sweeps clockwise. That’s, in fact, what defined clockwise in the first place.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Some of us in the North are jealous that 100% of the world’s population of free Penguins live in the Southern Hemisphere.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Earth is not only oblate — wider at the equator than pole-to-pole, but pear shaped — slightly wider just south of the equator
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Earth's centrifugal force at the Equator renders everybody and everything about 6% lighter than they’d weigh at the poles.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I think it's cool that there's a country on the equator with the name "Equator". Better known in Spanish as Ecuador
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Antarctica’s subglacial Lake Vostok is a body of water, trapped in ice, that hasn’t seen air in at least 15-million years.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The flag in Antarctica that ID's the South Pole has to be repositioned  every year. The glacier beneath moves continuously.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Toilet Bowls drain however they're designed to circulate water.  It’s irrelevant whether you live above or below the equator.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I don’t ever want Southern Hemispherians to feel neglected.  So I now offer some tweets just for lands down under...
author: deGrasseTyson

text: For survival in this world, it’s to an animal's great advantage if Humans think you're cute.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If your belief system is not founded in an objective reality, you should not be making decisions that affect other people.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Join me in congratulating @SethMacFarlane for asteroid 1999UL46 being officially renamed “70713 SethMacFarlane” in his honor.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Would be cool if be our lives, our planet, our solar system, our universe, were part of a data simulation conducted by aliens
author: deGrasseTyson

text: When Queen Elizabeth succeeded King George in 1952, I wonder why the United Kingdom wasn't renamed the United Queendom.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Tonight’s Super Moon fits easily within the field of view seen though a drinking straw.  I’m just saying.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: FYI: Every month, the Moon gets just as large as tonight’s Full Moon. During its New, Crescent, Half, or Gibbous phases.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: We pet dogs, expecting them to lick your hand or face in delight, but if a human licked your face you’d call the police.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Some claim the USA is a Christian nation, compelling me to wonder which assault rifle Jesus would choose: the AR-15 or AK-47.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: “How wonderful it would be if there were something out there, and they were all single & Jewish” -JoanRivers on StarTalkRadio
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Not that anybody asked, but still disgruntled that the “Alphabet Song" has the same melody as “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In any case, I want to live in a world where a chicken can cross the road without anybody questioning its motives.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Knee-slapping humor to a topologist: Question: Why did the chicken cross the Möbius Strip? Answer: To get to the same side.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Damn. One mystery solved & another rears its head: Which came first, the chicken salad sandwich or the egg salad sandwich?
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just to settle it once and for all: Which came first the Chicken or the Egg? The Egg -- laid by a bird that was not a Chicken
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happy 75th anniversary to The Wizard of Oz. Good to know (for future reference) that witches are water-soluble.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happy 75th anniv. to The Wizard of Oz. Gotta love it even though Lions & Tigers & Bears hail from three different continents.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The Perseids they're called -- a meteor shower these nights. But ruined, this year, by the Full Moon's light.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Mork from Ork: Rare evidence that aliens can be smart, clever, articulate & funny.  Robin Williams, RIP
author: deGrasseTyson

text: July’s full moon is to August's "Super Moon” what a 16.0 inch pizza is to a 16.1 inch pizza. I’m just saying.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Seems to me, as long as we don't program emotions into Robots, there's no reason to fear them taking over the world.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: When other mammals get bored, I wonder if they use this free time to contemplate their place in the universe, as humans do.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Dracula & other undead people who sleep in coffins must have good abs. They always rise up flat-backed when the casket opens.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The @UPS tracking uses 17 digits & one letter. Enough for 2.6 quintillion packages. That's 370 million per person on Earth.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: When a coincidence seems amazing, that's because the human mind isn’t wired to naturally comprehend probability & statistics.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If @Comic_Con people ruled the world, the future would be invented daily & warfare would be bar-fights with toy light-sabers.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Space Aliens better not land in SanDiego this week. Nobody would take notice. They'd blend right in with @Comic_Con attendees
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In cartoons, Lobsters & other Crustaceans that talk are typically drawn Red. But they’re that color only after you boil them
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The more oddly shaped your City's buildings are, the more likely they will be featured In photos for Travel Brochures.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: RT @Sara2Dee2: pic.twitter.com/1Ffa6XQCKN // Gotta love data.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Good thing Spanish fútbol sportscasters don’t announce basketball, they’d spend 1/3 of playing time saying “Goooooooooooool”
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Learned from Sportscasters on @Univision network that the word “Goal” in Spanish requires a full ten seconds to say.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Dear @TheTweetOfGod, after World Cup controversial calls, in what language do players&referees argue? Any lessons from Babel?
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Laws of physics describing gravity & energy conspire to make spheres (like the soccer ball) a common shape in the Universe.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: 64 games, 32 countries, 1 month of distraction from the workday. I wonder how much the world’s GDP drops during the World Cup
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I wonder what Rugby players think every time they see a Soccer player crying in pain from being grazed by another player.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Never liked the term “nonfiction".  The truth should have its own word, and not be shackled to its antonym.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In the sky this summer's eve, find high & nice, what many call a half Moon. "First Quarter" to be precise. It rose at noon.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Enjoying colorful fireworks tonight? Thank Aluminum Barium Calcium Chlorine Copper  Iron Nitrogen Oxygen Sodium & Strontium.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Seasons are caused by the 23.5-degree tilt in Earth’s axis. Without it, fashion would need a different excuse to change.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Earth is closest to the Sun in January -- "Perihelion".  But USA Astronomers celebrate the July 4th Aphelion with fireworks.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: July 4, 2014. At 94.5-million miles, Earth, in its oval orbit, is at "Aphelion" --  our farthest distance from the Sun.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Humans kill one another so often, for all reasons including none, I wonder how we'd treat a peaceful alien who visited Earth.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Q: Where do Attorneys got to get a drink?  A: The Bar
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just came up with a stupid joke that i'm compelled to share: Q: Where do Elephants go to get a drink?  A: The Ba-Bar.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: When aliens arrive on Earth & study our web infrastructure, they'd likely conclude cute cats are the engines of our Internet.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: There’s a very large array of radio telescopes in New Mexico.  As seen in the film Contact. We call it the “Very Large Array"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Want More?  The far side of the Moon is called “The Far Side of the Moon"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: No other scientific field rivals astrophysics in the transparency of its lexicon.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The titanic explosion that birthed all of space, time, matter, and energy we call the “Big Bang"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Jupiter’s big red spot is called “Jupiter’s Red Spot"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Generally in the universe we name things in ways that minimize confusion.  e.g. Spots on the Sun are called “Sun Spots"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Never knew why phobias are given long complicated names.  Afraid of today? Friday the 13th? You are Friggatriskadekaphobic.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: June's Full Moon crosses the sky lower than any other in the year, taking on an amber hue.  Granting the label “Honey Moon”.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: After filming the #CosmosFinale, @SethMacFarlane & I knocked back a cold one on the crescent Moon.pic.twitter.com/pTPFhcI1Hc
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Cosmos was a labor of love, an offer of hope, and a vision of a future that could be. Thanks for joining my SpaceTime Odyssey
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The film #AMillionWays to Die in the West would be numerically accurate if named A Million Occasions to Utter the Word F%&K

text: Apart from a badly oriented full moon, I give #AMillionWays an “A” for its sweeping & romantic portrayals of the night sky.

text: Was ready to count up to 1,000,000.  But #AMillionWays short-changed me. It showed only twenty-two ways to die in the west.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The block of ice portrayed in #AMillionWays would weigh about 2.5 tons. Enough to squash pretty much anything it fell on.

text: “Earthrise” — We travelled a quarter-million miles to explore the Moon, and discovered Earth for the first time.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: “Earthrise" — We were afloat in space. Seen not with color-coded countries, but as nature intended: oceans, land, clouds.

text: I'm enchanted to observe that in recent times the universe and its contents have risen to serve as the artist's muse.

text: Dec 21: The day with the least sunlight in the Northern Hemisphere — which means days get longer, not shorter, in the winter.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Dec 21: Happy Solstice to all people of the Earth.  And happy first day of Summer to residents of the Southern Hemisphere.

text: Need to cry, but don't want others to know? Look up to the stars. Your tears won't fall, and the cosmos will make you smile.

text: Actually, since days of the week are named for Gods, I instead bid "Happy Day 359" to all Atheists & Agnostics of the world.

text: To all Christians of the world: "Merry Christmas."  To Jews, Muslims, & everybody else not expecting Santa: "Happy Tuesday."

text: Random Santa Fact: Another casualty of global warming -- as the poles melt, most would rather not see Santa in a bathing suit

text: When Earth's oil runs out & price of other fuels rises then naughty children will thank Santa for giving them a lump-of-coal
author: deGrasseTyson

text: RandomSantaFact: Red-orange lights penetrate fog particles better than blue light. So Rudolph's nose is perfect for the task.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Santa surely keeps track of how many hours pass & how long the Elf union allows them to work, but time of day has no meaning.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Random Santa Fact: Longitude lines border Time Zones. So at the North Pole, where all lines meet, clock time has no meaning.

text: Every great journey begins with a single step, except if you've got a rocket. Then, it's the single step that ends it.

text: Things you might say if you flunked Astro101: "If we ever send humans to the Sun, it's probably best to go at night"

text: Done with Jury Duty. I said I could not convict a person solely on eyewitness testimony. They sent me home. I'm now 0 for 4.

text: Things you might say if you flunked Astro101: "I'm not in control of my life. The stars and planets are."

text: Last time, defendant was accused of selling 3000milligrams of cocaine. I told the Judge it was just 3grams. Was then sent home

text: Things you might say if you flunked Astro101: "The tide comes in. The tide goes out. You can't explain that."

text: Earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanic eruptions, tornadoes, floods, wildfires, hurricanes:  All the ways Earth wants to kill us.

text: Try not to think of science as a dose of unwelcome medicine, rather as a means of coming closer to the operations of nature.

text: Neil A. Armstrong 1930-2012. Farewell my friend. And now, perhaps more than ever, I bid you godspeed.

text: Apollo 11, July 1969.  No other act of human exploration ever laid a plaque saying "We Come In Peace For All Mankind"

text: "Men Walk On Moon" - The only positive event in the last 50 yrs for which everyone remembers where they were when it happened

text: Neil Armstrong was the spiritual repository of spacefaring dreams & ambitions. In death, a little bit of us all dies with him

text: Dear @MarsCuriosity, As for your complicated landing on Mars Sunday night 10:30pm PT -- do not try, do.

text: Dear @MarsCuriosity, We've got the #Olympics back here on Earth. But many of us will be focussed on you and your landing. Do us proud.

text: Dear @MarsCuriosity, What are your instructions if a Martian crawls onto your back and rides you like a Rodeo Bull?

text: Dear @MarsCuriosity, Scientists conceived you, engineers designed you. But seriously, who do you like better, Scientists or Engineers?

text: Dear @MarsCuriosity, You've been traveling for nine months. How did you pass your time? Did they let you play "Angry Birds Space"?

text: Dear @MarsCuriosity, Neil deGrasse Tyson here on Earth, tweeting you, via a wormhole, through deep space.  Do you copy?

text: Weightlifters, whose sole job is to raise barbells from planets that attracts them, on Mars achieve 2.6x their personal bests

text: Gymnastics: On Mars, with only 38% of Earth's gravity, the Vault & other spring-assisted leaps would resemble circus cannons.

text: If there was Swimming on Mars, the low temperature & low air pressure would force the pool to simultaneously freeze & boil.

text: June 20  7:09pm ET. Geekspeak: Sun reaches north-most spot on ecliptic above celestial equator. Everyone else: Summer begins.

text: The Hulk is GREEN from a potent, accidental dose of Gamma Rays. Actually, he would have died within weeks from organ failure.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Our eyes are about 10x more sensitive to GREEN light than Red. So watt-for-watt GREEN lasers look much brighter than Red ones
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The peak sensitivity of the Human Retina is GREEN, matching the peak spectral output of the Sun.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The Sun emits more GREEN light than any other band of light in the rainbow.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Curiously, light-loving GREEN plants reject the Sun's GREEN light, reflecting it back at you, which is why they look GREEN.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The laws of physics conspire to prevent GREEN stars in the universe. They basically come in three colors: Red, White, & Blue.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Area of a pizza (or any circle), is pi times radius squared. Volume of a pizza (or any cylinder) is the Area times the depth.

text: Of course the volume of that pizza is: V = pi zz a   “@Maz_Man_Utd: what about pizza volume if radius = z and thickness = a?”
author: deGrasseTyson

text: A 14 inch diameter gets you 154 square inches; a 10 inch gives 78 square inches; and a 7 inch, 38 square inches - of Pizza pi

text: If Pizza sizes were given in area not diameter, you'd see instantly that a 7 inch is less than half the size of a 10 inch pie

text: So, contrary to popular suspicion, seasons have nothing whatsoever to do with Earth's slowly varying distance from the Sun.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: But In July, Earth's Sun-tipped axis gives N. Hemisphere's middle latitudes a factor of 5x more sunlight than in January.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: During its January close-approach to the Sun, Earth receives about 7% more sunlight than it does during July's far-approach.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: SleepWell in 2012: Niburu is fiction; no Solar Max; Dec21 alignment occurs every yr; Mayan failed to predict their own demise
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Wow. I can remember the year 2011 as though it were yesterday.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: FYI:NewYear celebrations begin 6hr too early per yr, relative to Earth's orbital return spot. The 4yr leapday corrects for it
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Odd that we mark the New Year's exact moment - a fresh Earth orbit - yet celebrate it one time zone after another, 24 times
author: deGrasseTyson

text: .@jbg7 Concerned about which way "up" really is? "Up" is every direction away from Earth's center. That's the entire cosmos.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: As 2011 draws to a close, I remind us all that in life and in the universe, it is always best to keep looking up.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Good to see Apollo 11's Buzz Aldrin in a cameo spot. Yes, long ago, in a country that once was, astronauts visited the Moon.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: FYI: Catalog of astro-apps for mobile devices. Via colleague Andrew Fraknoi, for AstronomyEducationReview: bit.ly/skSZ5S
author: deGrasseTyson

text: When you can see the crescent Moon's unlit part it's called "Earthshine," but I've always preferred to call it "Moonshine"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: ...and why during sunset, when light passes through the most atmospheric crud, the Sun looks deep red & the sky, deep violet.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Long wavelength red-orange part of the spectrum passes thru fog/dust/pollen while short wavelength blue-violet gets scattered
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Christians: MerryChristmas; Jews & Muslims: HappySunday; Atheists & Agnostics: HappyDay359 (Days of week are named for gods)
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Red light cuts thru fog better than white. So if Rudolph's nose did glow he'd indeed prevent Santa from flying into mountains
author: deGrasseTyson

text: According to the song, Rudolph's nose is shiny, which means it reflects rather than emits light. Useless for navigating fog.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Seems that by now, given Santa's body weight & shape, hungry PolarBears would have mistaken him for a seal and eaten him.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: FYI: As the world warms & the Arctic melts, the PolarBear is not the only one to lose a habitat. Santa also gets cast adrift.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: To 2012ers: In a year, the Earth/Sun/Galaxy alignment that's supposed to end the world occurs every Dec 21. It's going on now

text: QUESTION: This year, what do Jews, Muslims, & Atheists call Christmas? ANSWER: Sunday.

text: Apollo in 1969. Shuttle in 1981. Nothing in 2011. Our space program would look awesome to anyone living backwards thru time.

text: The entire half-century budget of NASA equals the current two year budget of the US military.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The US military spends as much in 23 days as NASA spends in a year - and that's when we're not fighting a war.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The US bank bailout exceeded the half-century lifetime budget of NASA.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: NASA costs Americans half a penny on a tax dollar. That fraction of a bill is not wide enough from the edge to reach the ink.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just an FYI: Human access to space doesn't end with the Shuttle era, only American access. China and Russia still go there.

text: If Earth were size of a school-room globe, our atmosphere wouldn't be much thicker than the coat of lacquer on its surface.

text: FYI:  Commercial Space Flight will not advance the space frontier, but enable cheaper access to where we've already been.

text: Other than the waging of War, the ISS (assembled by Shuttle) is the most successful collaboration of nations there ever was.

text: Many lament the shuttle era's end. But that's misplaced sentiment. Lament instead the absence of an era to replace it.

text: While we're there: Water Vapor in air traps IR. That's why deserts cool precipitously at night. Humid places not so much.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Yup. One can never tire of the physics of light.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Time delay moves hottest time of day a few hrs after "high" noon & hottest time of yr a month or two after 1st day of summer.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: So, Sun's visible light doesn't heat air, it heats ground. Ground then re-radiates IR, which heats the air - a little later.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: N. Hemisphere bias is understandable. Nonetheless, Happy First Day of Winter to the 1 in 5 people who live south of Equator.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Summer solstice is longest day of the year. Which means days get *shorter*, not longer, in summer. Do the Astro.

text: The launch of Endeavour, for all those who slept through it.  Just posted: http://youtu.be/zBDD3s1YJPA
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In case you wondered: Space Shuttle Endeavour gets a British spelling because it's named for Captain Cook's ship.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Columbus took three months to cross the Atlantic in 1492.  The Shuttle takes 15 minutes
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just an FYI:  Within two minutes of flight, the Shuttle's air-speed exceeds that of a bullet fired from an M16 assault rifle.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Shuttle's orange fuel tank has 2 internal tanks. One for Hydrogen, 2x size as one for Oxygen, giving Energy plus H2O exhaust
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Birds at the launch site are surely thinking to themselves:  "These humans have come a long way with their artificial wings"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: 4) Water Tower dumps a swimming-pool's worth onto the launch pad -- H2O absorbs sound vibrations, preventing damage to craft
author: deGrasseTyson

text: 3) Sparks spray onto launch pad -- they burn away any potentially flammable hydrogen gathered there from the main engine.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Most of Shuttle's energy accelerates it horizontally rather than vertically. Go 17,200 mph sideways & you'd reach orbit too.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Most of the Shuttle's initial propulsion is to accelerate the mass of fuel that burns later in the launch.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Endeavor gets 2.4million lbs of thrust **more** than its 4.4million lbs of weight, giving about 1/2 G acceleration on liftoff
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Endeavor weighs 4.4million lbs. If engines gave only 4.4million lbs of thrust, forces would balance, leaving it afloat on pad
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In my NCAAwrestling days I dreamt of a hold I called the "Double Tidal Lock" inspired by Earth-Moon physics.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: We've already tidally locked the Moon -- it shows only one face to us. The Moon is trying hard to tidally lock us.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In about 10-billion years, Earth's rotation will have slowed enough that a day will equal the lunar month.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Since the 1970s we've added 24 "leap seconds" just to compensate for the Moon slowing down Earth's rotation.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Every year, the Moon's orbit spirals farther from Earth about five inches.  In response, Earth's rotation rate slows.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: On Moon's near side Earth goes through phases -- yet never sets. And full Earth is 60x brighter there than full Moon on Earth
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Also, the Moon-on-horizon illusion's all in the mind. Bend over & view Moon upside down thru your legs and effect goes away.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Images of huge Moons over trees & buildings used extreme zoom. Try with non-zooming camera -- the Moon's barely visible.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: RealityCheck: View "SuperMoon" while looking through an ordinary drinking straw. The entire Moon fits in your field of view.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Cost of laying off your science staff: @CNN reports the last full moon w/perigee was 1993. Actually, last time was Dec 2008
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Full moon at "perigee" Saturday. 14% larger than when at "apogee". No biggie. Same difference between an 8 and a 7-inch pizza
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Full Moon Sat. nite. Rare? Once per month. Moon close to Earth. Rare? Once per month. Both together? Once every 2 or 3 years.

text: The "GREEN" movement is surely misnamed. Experiments show increased CO2 promotes photosynthesis, making plants grow faster.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The Hulk is GREEN from a potent, accidental dose of Gamma Rays. Actually, he would have died within weeks from organ failure.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Our eyes are about 10x more sensitive to GREEN light than Red. So watt for watt GREEN lasers look much brighter than Red ones
author: deGrasseTyson

text: A reminder that Kryptonite, the only substance in the universe that can injure or kill Superman, is GREEN
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Curiously, light-loving GREEN plants reject the Sun's GREEN light, reflecting it back at you, which is why they look GREEN
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The peak sensitivity of the Human Retina is GREEN matching the peak spectral output of the Sun.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The Sun emits more GREEN light than any other band of light in the rainbow.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: The laws of physics conspire to prevent GREEN stars in the universe. They basically come in three colors:  Red, White, & Blue
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Sixty-four decimal places of Pi gets the observable universe's circumference down to a sextillionth the size of a proton
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Given that the digits of Pi never end (formally, it's a "transcendental" number) today is really only Pi-Approximation day.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Today is March 14, 2011.  Happy Pi Day (3/14) to all those who value pointless numerological distractions.

text: Dear world - deep lunar eclipse seconds away. If it's night where you are then look up. A good habit to have in any case.

text: FYI: Contrary to persistent journalistic claims, total eclipses are not rare. One every couple of years, for both Sun & Moon

text: To cameras, which do not suffer brain failures like humans, the Moon is the same size on the horizon as at the top of sky.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Upside down bldgs & mountns & trees don't register as familiar objects. Depth perception not confounded. Scene appears normal
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Next time you're stunned by large Moon on horizon, bend over and view it between your legs. The effect goes away entirely.

text: If your crickets are metric instead of American then count their chirps in 8 sec. Add 5. That should give air temp in Celsius

text: In the wilderness dusk with crickets chirping in harmony? Count their chirps in 15 sec. Add 40. You get air temp in deg F.

text: .@Stefaniya To cameras, which do not suffer brain failures, Moon is same size on the horizon as at the top of the sky.

text: .@leechdemon The perceived size of the Sun on horizon is subjet to same illusion (brain failure) as was affects Moon

text: .@CommonTense At horizon, atmosphere shrinks the Moon slightly, top to bottom. Moon-on-horizon illusion swamps this effect.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: .@naveedbhatti When Moon (240,000 mi away) is near familiar horizon stuff (10 mi away) it confounds your brain's depth cues.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: .@naveedbhatti The well-known Moon-on-Horizon illusion, where it looks improbably huge near the horizon, is all in the mind.

text: Cool experiment: Punch hole in side of paper cup full of H20. Drop cup into sink. While falling leaking H2O stops instantly.

text: An object in orbit has high sideways speed so it falls to Earth at exactly the same rate that the round Earth curves below it

text: Alas, Isaac Newton died a virgin. A fact offered without further comment.

text: Also, Newton would later invent ridges on coins. Prevented people from shaving off the valuable gold & silver they contained

text: .@DaveLugg When asked why planets orbit in ellipses & not some other shape, Newton had to invent calculus to give an answer.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: p.s. Isaac Newton: Smartest ever. Discovered laws of motion gravity & optics. Invented calculus in spare time. Then turned 26

text: .@JetForMe Don't confuse Julian calendar with Julian date. Nothing to do with each other.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: FYI: Gregorian Calendar began in 1584. Superior to Julian calendar, was not adopted by England or Colonists for centuries
author: deGrasseTyson

text: "Cinco de Mayo" was on May 5, 1862.  The "4th of July" was on July 15, 1776. Colonists were late to adopt Gregorian Calendar.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: .@cmact Any speed greater than 800 mph between NYC & SF would create a western sunrise -- you'd be outracing the time zones.

text: NY to SF. Flew 500 mph, due West. Chased sunset in a losing race. A bit faster, just 800 mph, & we'd freeze the Sun in place

text: Shuttle tanks filling now.  500,000 gals of liq. oxygen & hydrogen. Highly exothermic when they combine.  Byproduct: H2O

text: Dont know if we have fewer accidents. But to a physicist a car crash is a loud ballet, choreographed by Newton's laws of motion

text: Morning humor from @GreenIceT: What do you get when you merge cosmology with cosmetology?.  A really great looking universe!

text: Feb 4. Clyde Tombaugh's birthday. Discovered Pluto in 1930. His 96 yr old widow probably does not tweet. Regards to her anyway.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Okay everybody. "#Twypo" it is. Invented here?  twī - poh: An incomplete tweet sent by accident, making no sense to the reader
author: deGrasseTyson

text: @Orin420 Best school for cosmology?  College matters less.  Graduate School, many to choose from. Drop a note when ready to apply.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Taping for @PBS #NOVAscienceNOW today. Will drive snowplow at ski resort like supernova blast plowing gas and dust ahead of it.

author: deGrasseTyson

text: That some Americans use a Ground Hog's shadow to predict the weather -  further evidence of our sci-tech slide on world stage
author: deGrasseTyson

text: $3.8 trillion Fed budget. Hmm.  In $100 bills laid end to end is enough to circle Earth 125 times, then reach the Moon and back.

text: @ITsJUSTme8921 If you are indeed taking astrology  senior year then I have failed badly.  And  school  has failed  even more.

text: Seven years. February 1, 2003. Space Shuttle Columbia astronauts, RIP.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If you are scientifically literate, the world looks different to you:  #KCTS , Seattle:  http://bit.ly/9HTPQP
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Netflixed "Push" last night. Sensory powers of psychics tear up Hong Kong. Okay with that. Lesson to others: evidence matters.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Brain needs day off after sparring with @stephenathome Colbert last night. "Why something and not nothing?" he asks. Answer is...
author: deGrasseTyson

text: If you haven't found Mars yet, it's adjacent to the very full Moon tonight.  Spirit Rover, stuck forever there, RIP
author: deGrasseTyson

text: @elakdawalla  A touching comic indeed.  But if you're a rover and it's time to die, you can't beat Mars as a final resting spot.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: My one-year twitterversary is today  --  not that anybody should care.  Just spreading cosmic love, one tweet at a time.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Chillin' with Stephen Colbert tonite (Fri).  Live on stage. 7:30pm. Free to  public.  Montclair, NJ  http://bit.ly/9Go29W
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Sat over wing of #Boeing 757.Reminds me that Wright Bros first powered flight in 1903 was less than the winspan of this plane
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Redeye tonite back to NY. Solo travelers should be measured for leg length & assigned a seat that fits. Equal comfort for all.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: @GreatAuntMaude   I'd rather have the pen of a poet. But until then, I'm happy to settle for the soul.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: April 13, 2036 if killer asteroid Apohis hits,then Santa Monica is first to go. 50 ft tsunami from Pacific ocean impact.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Twilight skies over the Pacific. Gibbous moon. Orion perched  mightily. Mars rising in East. Santa Monica Beach under foot.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Mars is indeed close today, but context matters.  Beware the Mars "Virus":  http://tinyurl.com/yke6yp3
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Mars closest to Earth today. Jan 27, 2:02pm ET. 61,720,797 miles away. Reddish. Bright these nights. High in east after dark
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Some of you were not paying attention before. So here 's "The Known Universe"  http://bit.ly/6uWBIz  made in-house @atAMNH.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: @samvance Hypothetical companion to Sun, casting killer comets to Earth, was called Nemesis. Never found. Never existed.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Bright reddish object in the evening sky, rising in  east,  is  planet Mars.  But if it comes in for a landing, it's a plane.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I offer a  brief  but detailed account of what happens to your body when falling into a Black Hole:   http://tinyurl.com/y8ubsf9
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Aykroyd character in Ghostbusters cites 1909 for Tunguska meteor blast. Should' be 1908. The only scientific error in the film.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: More things learned at Ghostbusters 25th anniv. screening in LA. never before noticed that StayPuft marshmallow man is a sailor.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Things learned at the Ghostbusters 25th anniv. screening in LA. StayPuft man had only 3 faces: happy., surprised., & angry.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just drove by the huge , 30-ft tall L-A-X letters near the airport -- surely visible from orbit . Is LA an alien space port?
author: deGrasseTyson

text:
Off to LA from Phoenix. Freaky storm
finally passed. Busy week in LA ahead. Beginning with Buzz's b'day Saturday.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: No meteorites found in AZ. Just 4 meteorwrongs.  Piece of sheet metal. A wire. A rusty can. And a broken office-chair caster.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Remarkable that it's routine for 40tons of metal to fly 500mph at 37,000ft for 2,000mi. Yet we complain we don't get a pillow?
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Last day (Thu) to send 80th b'day wishes to Buzz Aldrin. I'll deliver them at a party in LA on Sat. http://tinyurl.com/yj62k55
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Still viral, made in-house, "The Known Universe" will likely take you where you've never been before. http://tinyurl.com/yh8k286
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I remain enchanted by the works of creative people for whom the cosmos serves as their artist's muse.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: I am living a reality because someone else had a dream....
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Bill Nye in town. About to have coffee with him on Upper West Side.  Will chat about changing the world -- a fave topic of his.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Offer 80th b'day wishes for Buzz Aldrin (Apollo 11). I will deliver them in person next week at party in LA: tinyurl.com/yj62k55
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Though accused of killing Pluto, I was just the messenger.  The real (confessed)  killer was Mike Brown @plutokiller.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Crossing the asteroid belt now.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Security area of American Airlines at LAX has 100-ft inlaid solar system embedded in floor. Standing on a 4-ft Saturn aright now.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: A suborbital x-country flight, which we should have all been taking by now, lasts about 16 min. I'd prefer that to airplane internet.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Interview with Earth & Sky radio just posted, if interested.  tinyurl.com/yfgc8c6  Mostly science literacy in America.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Dinner tonite w/ bio-gelogist Peter Ward, Univ. Wash. Proponent of Medea Hypotheses.  Opposite of Gaia. Earth wants to kill us.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: My #NPR interview on killer asteroid Apophis just posted, if interested: tinyurl.com/ybso5xy It begins 13 min into the recording.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Gotta love those Star Wars double sunsets. Half of all stars in night sky are double/multiple systems, including the North Star.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Re-saw original theatrical release of Star Wars. Happy to confirm that Han Solo did indeed shoot first.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Crisp clear skies over NY now. Jupiter sets shortly. Mars in east. Crescent Moon before sunrise. Might just unpack my telescope.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just taped for @earthskyscience radio. On life, the universe, and everything, of course.Pluto too. Will post URL when available.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Just taped interview with ABCs "Natures Edge."  Bill Blakemore called the Hayden a crime scene where Plutocide was committed
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In case nobody noticed, this past week Earth went faster around the Sun than during any other week of the year. About 1% faster.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: On Amtrak back to NYC from #AAS in DC. Peak 130mph. The year is 2010. Should be 300mph - and that would only equal China & Japan
author: deGrasseTyson

text: #aas In DC this week for a meeting of the nation's astrophysicists.    Heaven on Earth.  Media is full of our stories.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Glued to TV all day, for  the Twilight Zone marathon.  SyFy channel.  A annual ritual for all card-carrying geeks.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: "Blue Moon" rising New Year's Eve; the second Full Moon of the month.  Happens every 2.7 years, or so.  Last time on New Year's Eve was 1990
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Merry Christmas, Christians. Happy Friday, Jews and Moslems. Happy Day 359, Atheists (days are named for gods). As for Santa, I wanna Pony.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Happy Winter Solstice-Dec 21: 12:47 ET / 9:47 PT.  In Latin means "stopped Sun." Altitude of midday Sun pauses a few days then rises higher.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Nothing to tweet today, except that for all those who wanted more space, the universe continues to expand at 74 km/sec per Megaparsec.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: LIve today 1:30-2:00pm ET, on Leonard Lopate Radio Show, WNYC.  Streamable:  www.wnyc.org/shows/lopate/  Subject: The universe, of course.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Roast turkey once per year is too often. This year making pan-seared duck breast with apricot glaze. Mmmm. Happy Thanksgiving to all!
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Wondering what conundrums of logic will cause disturbances in the space-time continuum, like Pinocchio saying, "My nose is about to grow!"
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Wishing godspeed for space shuttle Atlantis.  Launching today (Monday).  Got some friends on this one.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Gearing up for the release of "2012." Wondering what to do with all those who think it's a documentary.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Richard Dawkins in town (NYC). Been a while since this first encounter: http://tinyurl.com/23j6qo He's still at it. And so am I.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: In Houston this week. At the "UP Experience."  A TED-like event where I must distill the cosmos into a 20-min talk -- or less if I want Q&A.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: This just in: New data (as of today) gives odds of Apophis hitting Earth on April 13,  2029 as 1 in 250,000, down from 1 in 45,000.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Last NOVA ScienceNOW of season tonite (Tue). A good segment on value of sleep to memory, forcing many to rethink all-nighters before exams.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: New treadmill coming to ISS. Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill. "COLBERT"  For details see /tinyurl.com/mz8mw5
author: deGrasseTyson

text: NOVA ScienceNOW airs tonite (Tue, Aug 25), features a segment on successful Hubble repair mission. Fun to film. Hoping it's fun to watch
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Does it disturb anyone else that "The Los Angeles Angels" baseball team translates directly to "The The Angels Angels"?
author: deGrasseTyson

text: "And that's the the way it was."   Walter Cronkite rest in peace.  On this 40th anniversary of Apollo 11.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Wondering how many who watched fireworks on July 4 did so because it's fun, forgetting that it commemorates exploding bombs during warfare.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Tyson's Tweets:  Who's really in charge?  One centimeter length of our lower colon carries more bacteria than all humans who ever lived.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Tyson’s Tweets:  I still can't get over the fact that "twelve plus one" uses the same letters that spell "eleven plus two."
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Tyson's Tweet's: Light travels one foot per nanosecond- a billionth of a sec. it travels 5.8 trillion miles in a year -- one "light year."
author: deGrasseTyson

text: John Grunsfeld reports from orbit:  "Neil, Now that Hubble is done the hard work will be on the ground to get the new instruments going."
author: deGrasseTyson

text: neiltyson Appearance on Glenn Beck today just POSTPONED.  Sorry for the false alarm.  Next time will tweet only after I'm in the seat.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: Will appear on Glenn Beck today - 5PM ET, Fox News Channel. Plan to teach some physics so that science, not politics drives  the discussion.
author: deGrasseTyson

text: At the Cape Monday for the Shuttle launch to service Hubble.   All good.

text: Saw IMAX World Premiere of "Star Trek"  NYC Wed Nite.  An orgy of Trekkedness.  Fans: " * * * * * ";  Everyone else " * * * * "
